results.title: From the ashes of war
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Nico Crama and Michael McKennirey
results.brief_description: This film uses stock shots, photographs, and rare archival film footage to document the liberation of Amsterdam by Canadian troops in May, 1945, and the events preceding it. Some of the worst battles, such as the Battle of the Scheldt and the crossing of the Leopold Canal, are shown. The film is narrated by Alex Colville, internationally known painter, who was an official war artist at the time. The film captures the horror of a people at war and testifies to the strong friendship that developed between Holland and Canada.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Nico Crama and Michael McKennirey

results.title: From the ashes
results.creator_credit: International Women's Film Project Productions, Glenn Silber and Helena Solberg Ladd
results.brief_description: A documentary tracing the history of Nicaragua from the presence of U.S. Marines in the early 1900s, through several rebellions to the problems of the present (up to 1981). The film focuses on the present efforts of the people to rebuild their country. Includes interviews.

results.title: From ten to twelve
results.creator_credit: Edmund Reid, Judith Crawley, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ages and Stages”.
Quite far removed from infancy, yet not across the threshold of adolescence, children of ten to twelve present an absorbing study of adults-in-the-making. We watch the children of one family in various situations in the home, at school and in group play, and find that much of their conflicting behavior is actually a normal part of the growing-up process.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edmund Reid, Judith Crawley, Crawley Films and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: From stone to bronze
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode 1 in the fascinating series called “Out of the fiery furnace.” Opening in the Stone Age this episode explores how mankind came to recognize metals, showing their accidental production in an Indian pottery kiln, and an experiment in smelting copper in the Sinai using Egyptian techniques of about 1500 BC.

results.title: From spirit to spirit (A)
results.creator_credit: Blackfella Films, Four Winds, Min Govat Productions, Nga Kara Whetu, TopShelf Productions and Great North
results.brief_description: An international co-production recognising the indigenous peoples of Australia, Canada, New Zealand and Sweden, made by indigenous filmmakers. The episodes reflect the amazing diversity of cultural tradition and heritage of indigenous communities.

results.title: From sociable six to noisy nine [col]
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Crawley Films and Judith Crawley
results.brief_description: The film looks into the meaning of various forms of conduct in children from six to nine years and suggests ways in which parents may guide them through a challenging, often trying phase of development. In a family with three children we observe how the parents cope with often baffling situations.

results.title: From silence to speech
results.brief_description: Training children to speak in Victorian institutions for the education of the deaf. It is essential that deaf children begin education early, and at the Princess Elizabeth Kindergarten, children are taught to lipread in order to associate lip movements with vocal sounds. As they grow older, children continue to the Victorian School for Deaf Children where they continue speech training, commence primary education, play games, learn handcrafts, carpentry and domestic training.
